Information Architecture – Wireframe Prototyping

– Wireframes to explain page strategy or to gain client approval for a new project can be very simple or complicated depending on the focus of the negotiation and the strategic objective. Wireframes are made in either Adobe Photoshop or Illustrator.

– When discussions are about specifying deliverables, such as functions and content objectives, design and style is purposefully avoided to keep focus on the content.

– Complex wireframes are created to explain design and usability to developers or as-needed by the client.

– Often a sketch can go directly to live prototype for review. However, creating a “rough” in Illustrator to workout ideas is sometimes worthwhile to save time and explore ideas.

– I write detailed technical specifications to define scope or explain the need and use for a dynamic element. I am able to convey intentions clearly to developers as well as in simple terms for the client.

– Technical specifications for developers require context as well as clear detail to ensure that the developer does not have to extrapolate meaning.

Integrated social media strategies


IcarusGroupIronwork.com

– Icarus Group’s website ranks on first page of Google for “iron work new york”

– Icarus Group’s social media is geared towards increasing SEO.


KosherWineSociety.com

– I acquired photography from Flickr.com to accompany text. I contacted the photographers to gain permission for use. I added credits with links where possible.


RandallsAutobodyNY.com

– I created Facebook and Twitter accounts for my client.

– I maintained the Twitter account. I wrote tweets, followed industry twitteratti and gained followers. I re-tweeted local businesses to gain brand loyalty.

– I re-purposed website copy into ads for craigslist.org. I posted ads on a regular basis to gain recognition on Google.

– Randall’s website ranks on second page of Google for “waxoyl”, and on first page top of Google for “waxoyl new york”


The importance of Content, UX and SEO:

– Websites that work without users needing to think build brand trust and gain results.

– UX and SEO are complimentary. Getting a consumer to your website first is critical. Once the user arrives on the website they become the most important focus.

– I assert that the copy that I write is the most important service that I provide. I research competitors to learn what services are typically offered and to build a library of searchable terms and phrases. I edit those product and service terms into concise copy. I re-edit the copy to compress the text as much as possible. Finally, I edit live on the web page for fit. Most importantly, I read the copy aloud to ensure that it sounds conversational.

– I concentrate primarily on the written content and presentation within the website. Searchable terms and phrases are incorporated into the text while striving for a natural tone or voice. The text should sound natural when read aloud. Keyword phrases are worked into section headlines. I incorporate search-content into cut-lines, alt tags, link titles and meta tags, making sure that terms are not repeated.

– Good content is recognized and highly ranked by Google, and is therefore both UX and SEO.

– Using HTML5, semantic elements are available to contribute to UX/SEO and accessibility.

– Much of the services content for Randall’s Auto Body appears on the Repair & Services Page. The content was later separated into individual pages and listed in the second tier of the top menu. We did it to make content easy to see and access through the menu, for users. The result is that important service pages appear on page One or Two, on Google.

– The Icarus website Product Page currently has six articles with planning for three more. I would have separated this content onto individual pages, except that the quantity of pages is limited by the project scope. That said, the HTML5 semantic structure clearly defines each article individually so that Google can recognize each article and evaluate it’s content value. It is also easy for clients to browse and see all of the services on one page. Additional navigational aids were created to direct users and Google.


Magento, Drupal, Wordpress and custom CMS:

– I built JungDesigns.net, http://www.JungDesigns.net/ using RapidWeaver, a CMS-like stand-alone program

– Using Microsoft’s OfficeLive, I built a website for Helping Hands for the Disabled of NYC, a Non-profit Service Organization. The website no longer exists. The current website (not mine) is HHDNYC.org

– I fixed the PHP, including a MySQL database, for a website baltimoreschoolofdoggrooming.com. The old PHP lacked POST tags so that when the website host updated their system the website no longer worked.

– My own Wordpress page. I’ve edited the format, updated the version of Wordpress, and successfully screened the blog for SPAM mal-ware.

– I experimented with Joomla! while building a prototype for the Kosher Wine Society. I have downloaded Drupal and Magento to explore. I build "modules" using PHP for websites, such as Randall’s and Icarus, that are added to the page as "includes".


Client Relationships:

– I’ve worked in many agency and corporate settings including many that are not listed on my resume. I keep client relationships confidential as needed.

– I listen to my clients to learn about their business needs and suggest a website structure that supports their business objectives. I am familiar with the pitfalls that can occur when objectives are not clearly defined. I work hard to avoid them.
